{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3495744,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-29T17:16:00.980Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone,
I’m writing some custom localization code, and I’m calculating the stddevs due to odometry every cycle.

Screenshot 2025-01-29 184236698×214 6.87 KB

stdX_addition and stdY_addition are the uncertainties associated with the odometry step, which should get added to the total stddev(uncertainty). But, when I check SmartDashboard, the std array is always 0 (std[0] and std[1]). So I thought that stdX_addition and stdY_addition could be the issue, but they always return non-zero. Intermediate also returns always 0. There is no other code simultaneously setting the stds back to 0 as far as I’m aware, so I’m confused as to why the std array is not changing.

If you want a deeper look, here is my github repo:

github.com

TheControlsExpert/CompetitionD1/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/Subsystems/Drive/Drive.java

package frc.robot.Subsystems.Drive;

import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.*;

import com.ctre.phoenix6.CANBus;

import edu.wpi.first.hal.FRCNetComm.tInstances;
import edu.wpi.first.hal.FRCNetComm.tResourceType;
import edu.wpi.first.hal.HAL;
import edu.wpi.first.math.Matrix;
import edu.wpi.first.math.VecBuilder;
import edu.wpi.first.math.Vector;
import edu.wpi.first.math.estimator.SwerveDrivePoseEstimator;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Pose2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Rotation2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Transform2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Translation2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Twist2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.interpolation.TimeInterpolatableBuffer;
import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.ChassisSpeeds;
This file has been truncated. show original

The code snippet is in the periodic function of the Drive file.

Any help would be appreciated pls

You are saying that “intermediate” comes out as zero on the smart dashboard?

Your understanding of arrays of doubles looks like it is correct. I would not call them “double arrays” because that is easily confused with a “two dimensional array” aka “a matrix”.

On line 615 you are setting std[0] = diff_x + std[0]; which could cause it to go back to zero if diff_x is -0.1. Maybe comment that line out and see if it is the culprit?

Other than that, it looks like std[0] should never be zero. You initialize it to a non-zero value private double[] std = new double[] {0.1,0.1}; and you are always adding a positive value to it, the result of an absolute value.

The problem seems more likely to be the configuration of your shuffleboard or your connection to the shuffleboard to me.

Other than that, I would urge you to format your code better. Your indentation is not consistent. Every closing brace should match the indentation of a corresponding opening brace. Every line that doesn’t have braces should not have changed indentation from the line before.

I’d also encourage you NOT to check in commented out code. It is fine to comment out code temporarily for testing, but in most cases, that commented out code should not make it back into source control. Git has ways of seeing old versions of code even if that code is removed.

I fixed it!!! I’m so happy right now.

Screenshot 2025-02-06 170533964×231 11.5 KB

I think this issue was that sometimes stdX_addition was so small it somehow confuses java into just turning everything into 0 (I’m far from a java expert, I’m more like a java caveman, so if you can offer a better explanation that makes sense I would still be happy).

I appreciate you trying to help me, and glad we got this solved

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T15:07:48.375Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":44.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":484127,"topic_slug":"confusion-about-how-double-arrays-work-in-java","display_username":"Emil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57904,"username":"stephen.ostermiller","name":"Stephen Ostermiller","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stephen.ostermiller/{size}/188076_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/confusion-about-how-double-arrays-work-in-java/484127/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3504054,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T16:52:52.178Z","cooked":"
GronkBaby:

somehow confuses java

I made a good living tracking down bugs in peoples’ code including compliers and OSes. The likelihood of Java being confused is nearly zero (admittedly not zero). There are instances (I simplify them) of Java and other programs purposely setting non-zero values to zero when they are too small to handle or are deemed too small to bother with.

The source of your confusion can (almost) always be determined (albeit it took me a year and a half once to find one bug that the system designers made a bad, undocumented assumption in the first couple of hours of developing a huge multi-year system). In your case the code has been changed as you debugged it and now you have moved on with what you are satisfied so no more exploration of this problem to find the root cause.

There is the minimum number that the system can handle. There is also the minimum increment that can be made to any other number. And with the SmartDashboard it has a somewhat small limit to the digits that are displayed - after all it is for quick view by people and not other exacting machines.

Here’s my test case somewhat resembling your code and Java handled it well.

  double[] std = {0.2, 0.2};
  public void setpose()
  {
    std = new double[]{0.1, 0.1};
  }
  public Robot() {
    setpose();
    std[0] += 0.000_000_000_001;
    System.out.println("std[1] " + std[1] + "   " + Math.ulp(std[1])); // std[1] 0.1   1.3877787807814457E-17
    std[1] += Math.ulp(std[1]);
    System.out.println("x, y " + std[0] + ",  " + std[1]); // x, y 0.10000000000100001,  0.10000000000000002
    SmartDashboard.putNumber("new test", std[0]); // 0.100000
  }

And you learned today that you can use “_” to breakup long strings of digits to make them easier to read.

If you want to see the smallest number, then print Double.min_value. It’s 4.9E-324 but anything less than the Math.ulp of a number is generally ignored.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T16:56:24.993Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":45,"readers_count":44,"score":9.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":484127,"topic_slug":"confusion-about-how-double-arrays-work-in-java","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/confusion-about-how-double-arrays-work-in-java/484127/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3504263,"name":"BillDunlap","username":"BillDunlap","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/7ea924/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T20:05:46.216Z","cooked":"

Floating point numbers are stored in “scientific notation” with a fixed number of digits of precision. To add them you need to make the exponents the same and if the exponents are too different all the non-zero bits of precision get pushed off the end and you end up adding zero to the bigger number. Look up the Wikipedia entry for floating point arithmetic to see how arithmetic on doubles (or floats) differs from ordinary arithmetic. Consult a book on numerical analysis if you need to sum up numbers of vastly different sizes (e.g., you can store them as their logs).

By the way, why are you adding standard deviations? Variances of independent random variables are additive but standard deviations (the square roots of the variances) are not. Try using Math.hypot() to accumulate standard deviations.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T20:05:46.216Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":31,"readers_count":30,"score":11.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":484127,"topic_slug":"confusion-about-how-double-arrays-work-in-java","display_username":"BillDunlap","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16385,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/confusion-about-how-double-arrays-work-in-java/484127/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3504280,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T20:17:51.470Z","cooked":"

That’s a very good point, I shouldn’t be adding stddevs. Thanks for finding that!

Also, I don’t think it adds 0 to the big number, from my testing, it literally sets the number to 0. stdX is initially set to 0.1, but after calling += with a positive number it would go immediately to 0.
